text: hi Nasima and i am back with a new
lesson on how you can talk about things
that you like things that you dislike
now there are several things that we
really like a lot in fact we really love
a lot and there are some things that we
plain dislike or really hate so let's
see the English expressions we use when
we are going to talk about those things
that we like dislike or maybe just love
now I will talk about what we use the
words we use to talk about when we love
something now what is it to love
something when you love something you
are expressing you know an extreme
passion or can I say an intense desire
for something so let's see what are the
expressions we use when we really love
something the first expression is I love
eating ice cream the word love is is in
the sentence because we're talking about
your intense desire because you really
love eating ice cream now what do you
not say if I say eating ice cream is fun
well you know I'm saying that I like
eating ice cream but I don't really love
it
so when I love something if you notice
the intonation in my voice kind of goes
a notch higher so I say I love eating
ice cream as opposed to eating ice cream
is fun which really means that I like
eating ice cream but I don't really love
eating ice cream okay now my next
sentence which shows that I really love
something goes something like I adore
sunbathing now the expression I have
used to denote or express my love for
sunbathing is the word adore
so again if you notice because of the
fact that I really intensely loved to
sunbathe I will say I adore sunbathing
now if I only liked to sunbathe and I'm
not really passionate about it what
would I say
I like sunbathing I don't adore
sunbathing I kind of like sunbathing so
that's the difference in intonation when
you love something as opposed to just
liking something and then we have a
sentence like she's crazy about John
crazy about all I could say she's mad
about the guy she met last night so when
I'm talking about
being crazy about or being mad about I'm
talking about an intense desire you know
an extreme passion for a thing or a
person but what would I say
if I just liked a person or I was not
quite into that person I would say she's
fond of John she kind of likes John she
thinks he's fun but she is she does not
love him she's not crazy about him so
therefore the intonation and my voice
kind of dips when I talk about just
liking somebody or something well there
are some things that we neither like and
we don't dislike either
so this is kind of a tricky thing to
express when we are trying to use
English expressions so what do you use
when you neither like something and you
don't quite dislike it either if
somebody were to ask me do you like
doing housework housework meaning
household chores like
meaning swabbing you know doing the
dishes you know the stuff well what
would you say well there are some of you
who don't know what to say because you
don't like it and then you don't dislike
it either so you say something like yeah
it's okay yeah it's okay well does that
sound correct well you could say
something like I don't mind doing
housework so next time if somebody were
to ask you a question about something
you're not very sure about you can use
the expression don't mind I don't mind
doing housework I don't mind taking my
dog for a walk
I don't mind babysitting okay now well
if someone were to now ask you whether
you want to go to the park or do you
want to go to the beach
a lot of you can't make up your mind as
to what you need to say because you
don't really mind doing anything you
neither like the park you don't dislike
the park either
but then you don't care about the beach
you don't dislike it you don't like it
either so a lot of you say something
like yeah whatever yeah whatever
that sounds really very uncertain
doesn't it well I have a better
expression you could say I don't really
care either way that shows that you are
not really concerned about whether you
go to the park you go to the beach you
go for a movie because you don't like it
and you don't dislike it okay now if I
were to ask you do you want to study
physics or do you want to study
chemistry or let me take some easier
subjects I could say do you want to
study English or do you want to study
French
now some people again say yeah whatever
um it's
it's okay or both are so-so expressions
like these are not correct English
expressions they're just used as fillers
okay so when you want to talk about
something that you don't like and you
don't dislike either you could say it's
all the same to me so instead of saying
yeah whatever it's so-so it's okay you
can say it's all the same to me let's
study English or French because it's all
the same to me
all right we'll now look at some other
expressions which talk about what we use
when we don't like something or when we
hate something well there are some
things that we dislike and there are
some things that we purely hate in fact
we just can't stand it we can't stand
being near those things or those people
so we're going to look at some
expressions which talk about how we need
to express the things we hate and then
there are some expressions that talk
about things that we just dislike okay
there is a difference between the two
we'll see why okay the first sentence
which talks about how much I hate
something is I can't stand my boss okay
so I use the word the expression can't
stand so when I say I can't stand my
boss you can see that my voice goes a
little bit higher because I'm really
frustrated you can see the hatred it is
evident in my tone of voice okay but if
my boss was someone that I just kind of
disliked okay I would say something like
I don't quite like my boss do you see
the difference in the tone of my voice
when I say I don't like where I don't
quite like my boss my voice the
intonation is at an even level it is not
high as opposed to saying I can't
stand my boss okay so there is a
difference in the expressions we use
when we hate somebody as opposed to
someone we just dislike to a certain
extent now my next sentence is I detest
being late I detest it or I intensely
hate I intensely dislike being late
again if you notice the intonation the
tone of my voice goes a little higher
because of the hatred for being late but
if I were someone who is not quite you
know very fond of being late I would say
something like I dislike being late okay
I'm not really frustrated when I say
this and therefore when I say I dislike
being late the intonation in my voice
does not go as high as me saying I
detest being late okay now a lot of you
are golf fans so please excuse me okay
but there are some of us who don't like
golf
in fact we hate golf so we can say
something like I can't bear watching
golf
I can't bear watching football for some
of you who don't like football as
opposed to those people who are ok with
golf they don't like it but you know
they don't hate it
either so they could say golf isn't
really my thing
ok so if you you know if you don't like
something you can say horse riding isn't
really my thing or golf isn't really my
thing or cricket isn't really my thing
but if you intensely dislike it if you
hate it you should say I can't bear
watching this game for the third time ok
now our next sentence which shows
intense hatred is the expression low
in the sentence which says I loathe
bacon bacon which is something we eat I
loathe bacon which means I intensely
hate it I can't stand it
okay but if you were someone who didn't
mind eating bacon even though you don't
really like it you would say something
like I'm not very fond of bacon so the
expression that you use is I'm not very
fond of bacon or or of beans or french
beans whatever you know it is that you
eat so loathe when you use the word
I loathe bacon your voice rises up a
notch as opposed to saying I'm not very
fond of bacon wearing your voice is
maintained at a pretty even level
alright what that brings me to the end
